item.title: Good Articles
item.description: In Praise of Idleness – Bertrand Russell, Harper’s Magazine, 1932 The String Theory – David Foster Wallace, Esquire, 2008 Mysterious Circumstances: The Strange Death of a Sherlock Holmes Fanatic – David Grann, The New Yorker, 2004 Frank Sinatra Has a Cold – Gay Talese, Esquire, 1966 The Personal Analytics of My Life – Stephen Wolfram, 2012 Why Books Don’t Work – Andy Matuschak, 2019 Insulation: First the Body, Then the Home – Low Tech Magazine, 2011 The Chameleon: The Many Lives of Frédéric Bourdin – David Grann, New Yorker, 2008 Top Five Regrets of the Dying – Susie Steiner, The Guardian, 2012 Take With You A Go-With-Me: Making Your Own Wisdom – Quentin Broughall, 2018

item.title: The Butchering Art
item.description: ⊕ Rating: 7/10 Read: March 10th, 2022 Pages: 304 Year: 2017 ISBN: 0141983388 Summary & Review A look at Sigmund Freud, William Halsted and the birth of cocaine. It explores how the two men were enraptured by the promise of the new miracle drug but how ultimately its clinical application was limited, while the personal usage by the two men was unlimited. Freud seemingly shook off his cocaine addiction, Halsted never quite did.

item.title: An Anatomy of Addiction
item.description: ⊕ Rating: 7/10 Read: March 10th, 2022 Pages: 336 Year: 2012 ISBN: 1400078792 Summary & Review A look at Sigmund Freud, William Halsted and the birth of cocaine. It explores how the two men were enraptured by the promise of the new miracle drug but how ultimately its clinical application was limited, while the personal usage by the two men was unlimited. Freud seemingly shook off his cocaine addiction, Halsted never quite did.

item.title: About me
item.description: Hello! Favourites Movies Lord of the Rings Trilogy In Bruges Withnail & I Hot Fuzz The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo Blade Runner Shame Four Lions About Time Barry Lyndon TV Shows True Detective (Season 1) Peep Show Game of Thrones The Office (US) I’m Alan Partridge Blackadder Taboo Penny Dreadful This Country Detectorists Music My favourite genre is rock and folk from the 1960’s and 1970’s.

item.title: About this site
item.description: Clowes.org is the homepage of me, Elliot Clowes (hi there!). Essentially it’s just a place for me to put my writing, photos and general thoughts online. I do also write two blogs. One is about technology. And the other is a microblog, and about anything and everything. I enjoy writing them. But the problem with blogs is that every post is treated equally and their chronological layout means things you consider important gets lost on page 17, alongside the quickly hammered hate-post you wrote on a movie you hate.

item.title: Music
item.description: Album Reviews Cowboy Reach for the Sky (1971) Starts a little quirky, but settles as the album goes on. This is a nice and soft country rock-ish album. 7/10 Stand out songs: Pretty Friend, Everything Here, It’s Time and Josephine Beyond Compare.

item.title: Examples
item.description: There is nothing more beautiful than an elegant mathematical proof. Shawn This is an example of an epigraph with some math $ \mathbb N \subseteq \mathbb R $ to start the beginning of a section. Author Writer, Math is Fun (what am I up to now?) After a certain amount of analysis paralysis, Some sidenote I decided I could announce my structure intentions here and iterate.

item.title: Favourite Quotes
item.description: This is a collection of screenshots of cosy cabins, rooms and houses I’ve stumbled upon whilst watching television and films. They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old; Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. At the going down of the sun and in the morning. We will remember them. For the Fallen by Robert Laurence Binyon

item.title: Film ratings
item.description: Score meanings 90% = Masterpiece: Life changing stuff. 80% = Amazing: One of the films of the year. 70% = Good: Certainly worth a trip to the cinema. 60% = Decent: Flawed, but still watch it. 50% = Average: Only if you’ve got spare time and like the genre/actor/etc. 40% = Disappointing: Not worth your money and watch it in the background. 30% = Bad: Don’t watch it. 20% = Terrible: Really don’t watch it.

item.title: Tech setup
item.description: I’m a big fan of The Setup. It’s “a collection of nerdy interviews asking people from all walks of life what they use to get the job done.” So in the spirit of it, I’ve decided to do my own. You can can see previous editions: 2013, 2014 and 2016. My initial plan was to do a new one each year, but s you can see I have failed in my duty.

item.title: The Victorian City
item.description: Highlighted Sections Dickens now did something extraordinary. Nine months before he finished Pickwick Papers, this man of prodigious energy, only twenty-five years old, began to write Oliver Twist, one of the world’s most famous novels, whose ‘Please, sir, I want some more’ is familiar even to the millions who have never read it. And then, five months after he completed Pickwick, he started his third novel, Nicholas Nickleby, before Oliver Twist, his second, had reached its halfway point.

item.title: Hugo-Tufte Features
